143.title: Marmalade Boy
143.author: by Wataru Yoshizumi.
notes: Summary: "All Miki Koishikawa wanted was an ordinary family, and that's exactly what she had. Then one fateful day her parents met the Matsuuras, and turned Miki's world upside-down. Now she lives in a house with four parents and her new stepbrother, Yuu, who is a total jerk. Make that a totally cute jerk. It's bad enough being brought into her parents' strange soap opera, but Miki will star in a soap of her own when she ends up torn between her long-time crush, Ginta, and her new stepbrother."

188.title: "Yataca : Fils de la Couleur"
188.author: Dominik Vallet
188.appears_in: text p. 69-79 in Cap'tain Swing, no. 113 (Août 2003).
notes: Describes the periodical Yataca, which started as a medium-sized color comic in 1968, then after 20 issues became a small-format black and white. It lasted 254 issues and until 1989. After a biographical sketch of artist Denis McLoughlin (1918-2002) the major series of the periodical are separately described: Yataca (a South American jungle adventure), Les Diables de Paxton, Marney le Renard, Marsimonstre, Antares, La Famille de Nohey, Chuck Batson, Dave Wheeler, Goal Keeper, Kangourou Kid, Les Cybernétiques, Roy et ses Diables, Mizomba, Ricky, Ron Camaro, & Ron Flash. 204.heading: Marone, Shad.
204.title: Law of the Desert Born : a Graphic Novel
204.author: Louis L'Amour ; adapted by Charles Santino ; script by Beau L'Amour and Katherine Nolan ; based on the short story by Louis L'Amour ; produced by Beau L'Amour ; illustrated by Thomas Yeates.
notes: Summary (from publiher via SkyRiver): "The first graphic novel adaptation of the work of master storyteller Louis L'Amour is a dynamic tale of the Old West that explores the borderlands of loyalty and betrayal with the emotional grittiness of a noir thriller. New Mexico, 1887, a land in the midst of the worst drought anyone can remember. Family histories and loyalties run deep, but when rancher Tom Forrester has his access to the Pecos River cut off by the son of his old partner, he convinces his foreman, Shad Marone, to pay Jud Bowman back for the discourtesy. Yet what starts as a simple act of petty revenge quickly spirals into a cycle of violence that no one can control. Now Marone is on the run, pursued by a sheriff's posse across a rugged desert landscape. Leading the chase is Jesus Lopez, a half-Mexican, half-Apache with a personal stake in bringing Shad to justice. Newly released from jail, trusted by no one, Lopez swears he's the only man who can track Marone down. That may be true. But who will live and who will die and what price will be paid in suffering are open questions. Fate and the Jornada del Muerto desert possess a harsh justice that is all their own."

311.heading: Marpa, Gabriel.
311.title: "The Lord of Cats" p. 13-23 in The Three Ears
311.author: Alejandro Jodorowsky - Georges Bess ; translation by Justin Kelly.
notes: (The White Lama ; 3)

Summary: Gabriel begins his life as a novice monk by vanquishing the reigning bully, Topden. The next night, after a horde of cats has been brought in to watch the temple, the Topden wants to be friends and shows Gabriel how to get past the cats by giving them mice. Gabriel refuses to sacrifice the mice, but rather makes friends with the top cat, named Lin-Fa.

312.heading: Marpa, Gabriel.
312.title: "Trial and Miracles" p. 3-12 in The Three Ears
312.author: Alejandro Jodorowsky - Georges Bess ; translation by Justin Kelly.
notes: (The White Lama ; 3)

Summary: Gabriel Marpa arrives at the monastery and is made to sit motionless in the courtyard for three hot days and three freezing nights. Snails come to cover and cool him in the day, and a blanket blows his way in the night. Little Jesus is shown eating pork, though the eating of animals is supposed to be forbidden.
